Event description: Granted in part
The Court dismissed the case.
Applicants sought to annul Commission decision rejecting part of the German Phase II national allocation plan (NAP).
the court upheld the Ministry's decision to deny access to the documents requested.
Flachglas Torgau requested information about Germany's allocation of emissions licenses during 2005-2007, denied on the grounds of confidentiality. Flachglas challenged this decision.
The court dismissed the action as inadmissible.
Applicants in the above actions challenged the Commission of the European Communities' decision rejecting the Polish Phase II national allocation plan (NAP) .
The Court held that the Italian law was precluded since guarantees of origin fall within an area largely covered by EU law.
Italy referred the case to the European Court of Justice.
The Court dismissed all actions as inadmissible.
Applicants challenged the Commission of the European Communities' decision rejecting the Polish Phase II national allocation plan (NAP)
The European Court of Justice rejected the electricity producers arguments
The case was referred to the European Court of Justice.
Electricity producers challenged Spain's amendment to its system for purchasing wholesale electricity.
The Court dismissed all actions as inadmissible because the Commission's decision did not directly and individually affect the Applicants.
Lafarge Cement challenged the Commission's decision to reject the Polish Phase II national allocation plan (NAP) for the allocation of GHG emission.

The Advocate General answered that ‘dual use' within the meaning of Article 2(4)(b) refers to where coal is used as heating fuel in a lime-kiln in order to generate carbon dioxide for the production of lime-kiln gas, which is subsequently used for the purification of the raw juice obtained from sugar beets, that process giving rise to the by-product earth foam

Advocate General Sharpston was asked for guidance as to the meaning of the term ‘dual use' in the second indent of Article 2(4)(b) in relation to sugar production and lime fertilizer, the by-product arising from that process, of the Directive 2003/96/EC.
The court found that the Commission made an error of law in rejecting the amendments proposed by the UK as inadmissible.
The UK challenged the European COmmission's decision to reject its amendments to its NAP.
The Court held that the Commission did not properly examine the NAP and infringed on the principle of sound administration.
Estonia challenged the European Commission's decision that its National Allocation Plan was inconsistent with Directive 2003/87.
The Court held that this decision exceeded the commission's authority.
Poland challenged the European Commission's decision that its National Allocation Plan was inconsistent with Directive 2003/87.
The General Court rejected all 4 grounds and the action was dismissed
Poland challenged the adoption of Directive 2003/87/EC on 4 grounds.
The Court concluded that the gift tax was inconsistent with Article 10.

the Czech Republic requested a preliminary ruling from the European Court of Justice on the question of whether Article 10 of Directive 2003/87 precludes application of the Czech gift tax to emissions allowances obtained free of charge.
The Court found that the differences were justified, dismissed the claim.
Arcelor challenged the adoption of Directive 2003/87 under the principle of equality.
The Court of Justice found Walloon's interpretation of biomass (excluded because of negative imapcts) was permissible under the Directive given its purpose.
The Constitutional Court of Belgium referred these issues to the EU Court of Justice.
The European Court of Justice held that the directive did not violate the principle of equality

The French Constitutional Council upheld the validity of article 64 regarding the purchase of GHG emissions quotas for 2011, whereas quotas were distributed free of charge in 2010. The quota purchase will only apply for 2011 and 2012. This had been challenged by some companies that hadn't received their quotas even though they carried out activities in 2010.

French Constitutional Council annulled a tax on carbon emissions (set at 17 Euro/CO2et) on the grounds that the proposed tax contained too many exemptions and would not have applied to 93% of industrial emissions.
The Administrative court granted the application, rejecting the argument that information on German export credit activities did not constitute “environmental information”ù.

BUND and Germanwatch brought suit against the government arguing that citizens have a right to the free access of environmental information under the German Access to Environmental Information Act (UIG).
The Court dimissed the suit arguing the Ministry is responsible to “inform and educate the public about environmental issues”ù, this includes presenting all points of view.

The NGT in its own motion concluded that the government of Himachal Pradesh had violated its obligations by failing to restrict development and road and pedestrian traffic in and around the increasingly touristed area accessible via the Rohatang Pass (it should Halt and reverse receding of glaciers near Rohatang Pass).
The High Court granted the appeal and overturned the permission.
An Taisce and Friends of the Irish Environment challenged the approval of Edenderry Power Ltd.'s application to extend operation of its peat- and biomass-burning power plant from 2015 to 2023.
The Environment Court of NZ upheld the decision, granting the permit for the project.
The Supreme Court of NZ agreed that GHG emissions should be considered, overturning the decision of the court of Appeals.
The Supreme Court denied the Appeal.
Mr. Teitiota appealed the decision of the Court of Appeal.
The High Court refused the leave to appeal from that decision.
A Kiribati citizen appealed the denial of refugee status in the New Zealand High Court (Decision of the High Court 25/06/2013)
Meridian appealed this decision.
The High Court of New Zealand allowed the appeal and remanded the case back to the Environment Court.
The Environment Court dismissed the appeal, questioning the efficacy of imposing mitigation measures.
The court held, under the Resource Management Act 1991, that a consent authority can consider the effects of such discharge on climate change.
Greenpeace challenged a regional council's decision to consent to a proposed coal-fired power station.
The court dismissed the IMVIA's application for review.
The appeal was granted based on other reasons, the Tribunal explicitly declined to reach the question of whether climate change provided a basis for granting resident visas.
A family from Tuvalu appealed after they were denied New Zealand resident visas on the grounds that if deported to Tuvalu they would face adverse impacts of climate change.
The Court upheld the decision.
The court agreed with the City Council and held that the turbines would have significant adverse landscape impacts. It declined the appeal for all but 4 turbines.

The High Court held that the research institute had used credible scientific methods to carry out its work and there was no basis for judicial review. It ordered the Trust to bare the costs of the judicial action. The trust appealed this decision, and the appeal was dismissed.
The Court found that the Minister had not done any reviewable error, hence the claim was dismissed.

Sarah Thomson, a New Zealand law student, filed a Statement of Claim against New Zealand's Minister of Climate Change Issues alleging that he had failed in several respects regarding the setting of GHG emissions reduction targets required by New Zealand's Climate Change Response Act of 2002.
The High Court found no error as a matter of law and dismissed the appeal.
Unison Networks Limited  appealed this decision.

The Supreme Court overturned the previous decisions, concluding that the lower courts had wrongly construed the Act. It held instead that such considerations for cliamte change were not just permissible but obligatory.
The High Court upheld the decision by the Environment Court.
The Environment Court granted consent, on the grounds that under the Resource Management Act it wasn't necessary to have regard for the effects on climate change.

Buller Coal Ltd. and Solid Energy Ltd. applied for consent to operate a coal mine for export purposes, they sought consent from the Environment Court that the end use of the coal was irrelevant to the resource consents.
The court held that the practice of gas flaring is unconstitutional as it violates the guaranteed fundamental rights of life and dignity.
Jonah Gbemre, a representative of the Iwherekan community in the Niger Delta filed suit against the Nigerian government and Shell to stop stop flaring gas in the Niger Delta.

Rabab Ali, a 7-year-old girl challenged to various actions and inactions on the part of Pakistan's federal government and on the part of the Province of Sindh regarding climate change. Judgement is pending.
The court issued supplemental decision naming 21 individuals to the Climate Change Commission and vesting it with various powers.
The court determined that "the delay and lethargy of the State in implementing the Framework offend the fundamental rights of the citizens, and created a Climate Change Commission.

Event name: Petition filed by Greenpeace Asia and Others

Event description: The Court found that the government was justified in applying the maximum penalty of 55% over the total 2000-2002 historical emissions for that category of emitter.
UniÃ_n Fenosa GeneraciÃ_n brought suit against a decision of the Council of Ministers whereby it approved the assignment of emissions allowances to two of the company's power plants.
The court ruled in Faraneto's favor and changed the assignment to a total of 174,508 tons for the 2005-2007 period.
The court found in Minera Catalana's favor

Minera Catalana Aragonesa brought suit against the General Government Administration of Spain challenging the decision approving the individual assignment of emissions credits to its ceramics facility
The court denied Cerámica's petition.
Cerámica Hermanos Fernández brought suit against the General Government Administration of Spain challenging the decision approving an individual assignment of emissions credits to its facility.
The Court dismissed the petition.
Cerámica Dolores GarcÃ_a Bazataqui brought suit challenging the decision of the Council of Ministers of Spain that declared the individual assignment of emissions allowances for the 2005-2007 term.
The Court found in favor of plaintiffs.
The Court rejected Arcelor's arguments and dismissed its request for remedy
The Ministry of the Environment was ordered to conduct a new assignment of credits.
The Ministry of the Environment was ordered to conduct a new assignment of credits.
The court ruled in favor of Cales de Llierca and ordered the Council to conduct a new assignment of credits.
The Court annulled the individual assignment of emissions credits and ordered that a new calculation take place in harmony with its findings.
Court found that the decision of the Council was invalid and ordered the Council to conduct the assignment of credits anew.
Segura, S.L., brought suit against a decision of the Council of Ministers of Spain which approved the assignment of emission credits to the company.
Court found that rules setting standards for SO2 emissions were null and void since they weren't specifically authorized by Spain's implementing statute for the EU's Directive 2003/87/EC.

Event name: Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights relinquished jurisdiction in favor of the Grand Chamber of the Court

Event description: The Advocate and Procurator General, independent judicial officers, issued a formal opinion recommending that the Supreme Court uphold the decision. The case is yet to be decided.
The Hague Court of Appeal upheld the District Court's ruling, concluding that by failing to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 25% by end-2020, the Dutch government is acting unlawfully.
The Dutch government appealed the decision before the Netherlands' Supreme Court.
The court in the Hague ordered the Dutch state to limit GHG emissions to 25% below 1990 levels by 2020.
Environment-People-Law (EPL) filed suit against the government, seeking to compel the dissemination of information on international greenhouse gas emissions trading. Case still not decided.
The Ministry of Environmental Protection filed an appeal.
The Commercial Court of Lviv Region ruled a decision in favour of EPL
Environment-People-Law (EPL) sought to compel the Ministry of Environmental Protection to develop a climate change policy for Ukraine
The claim was dismissed.

Tate & Lyle requested judicial review of their allocation of 1.0 Renewables Obligations Certificates (ROC) for the use of co-firing of biomass with combined heat power (CHP) ( they argued they shuld have recieved 1.5)
The court determined that the given sentences were too high and reduced the sentences to 13 years, 10 years and 8 years.
The defendants were convicted for the manipulation of the EU Emissions Trade Scheme.
The Planning Inspector affirmed the local council's decision, concluding that the adverse visual effects in this particular case outweigh the need for renewable energy
Cumbria Wind Farms Ltd. appealed local council decision refusing planning permission for the erection of six wind turbines near a national park.
The Court classified EUAs as intangible property at common law. Hence, EUAs may be subject to restitutionary claims, and Armstrong was entitled to a money judgment.

Armstrong was affected by a fraudulent email which resulted in the transfer of some of its EUA to Winnington. The case is to decide which party should bare the costs of the fraud. Armstrong filed a claim on 3 alternative bases.
the court held that the government had considered the impacts of the proposed development on climate change. The application was dismissed.
“Stop Stansted Expansion”ù challenged the grant of planning permission relating to the increase in capacity of Stansted Airport (decision from 08/10/2008)
The court found that the government's approach to consultation was sufficient and dismissed the claim.
Claimants opposed the designation of two locations as proposed “ecotowns”ù arguing the process had insufficient consultation.
The administrative court found that the proposed wind turbines would have a significantly detrimental effect on the historic landscape.
Bellis (Corp) appealed the decision of a local planning authority in Wales to deny the application to construct 3 wind turbine generators in a Historic Landscape Area.
The Inspector decided the benefits are outweighed by the unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the distinctive local landscape.
The court found that the Minister's determination that there were impermissible flood risks at the site was fair and reasonable. Appeal dismissed.
Claimants challenged the decision by the Welsh Ministers to refuse to grant a planning permit for a mixed-use redevelopment.
The Court dismissed the application.
Cemex UK field a claim arguing that Phase II of the National Allocation Plan (NAP) seriously disadvantaged one of its plants, violating the principle of equity.
The court held Barclays and Tricorona jointly liable for each other's breaches of confidentiality
CFP brought suit against Barclays and Tricorona for misuse of condidential information.
Planning Inspector found that the proposals would provide significant benefits, permit was upheld.
Local residents challenged two proposals for the construction of wind turbines, arguing that the harms outweighed the economic or environmental benefits.
The Planning Inspector concluded the harm that the proposal would cause to the surrounding landscape outwighed the beenfits.
A construction company appealed a local council failure to determine within the prescribed period an application for the erection of 3 wind turbine generators.
The Inspector found that these benefits clearly outweighed the possible harms.
Local residents challenged two proposals for the construction of wind turbines.
The Planning Inspector concluded that the proposal would unacceptably harm the surrounding landscapes, dismissed the appeal.
The Court ordered TGS to pay damages to DB.
Deutsche Bank (DB) sued Total Global Steel (TGS) for breach of contract for the sale of Certified Emissions Reductions (CERs).
The claim was dismissed.
Local residents challenged the decision of a Planning Inspector to grant permission for the development of a wind farm.
The court found for the Claimant, the permit was granted.
Claimant appealed the denial of planning permit for a residential development where a similar proposed development was approved for the same property by the previous landowner.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal dismissed the appeal
The Court ruled that the process was flawed, but didn't quash the order, it granted declaratory relief.
Greenpeace challenged the decision to develop new nuclear plants in the UK arguing the consultation process for the project was flawed.
The court agreed with the petitioners and quashed the Secretary's decision.
Hertfordshire County Council challenged the decision of the Secretary to grant permission for urban expansion (decision from 1/02/2012)
A UK court granted injunctive relief to control a probable campaign of direct action and civil disobedience by environmental activists in the immediate vicinity of Heathrow airport.
The Court ruled the Commissioner failed to properly consider the benefits of the wind farm and granted the permit.
The applicants sought judicial review of a Planning Commissioner's refusal to their permit request before the Planning Appeals Commission.
The Quinn brothers requested a permit to develop a renewable energy wind-farm in their lands in Northern Ireland, the request was denied.
The court upheld the appeal and quashed the Inspector's decision.
Community members challenged an Inspector's decision to overturn the refusal of an application to erect a wind turbine (decision from 19/03/2012).
Court acquitted climate change activists of causing criminal damage at a coal-fired power station.
The Inspector granted the permission.
KS SPV35 Ltd. appealed the Monmouthshire County Council's rejection of its application to install a solar farm.
The court overruled the Secretary's decision
Lark Energy Ltd. challenged the decision of the Secretary for State Communities (Secretary) to dismiss its appeal against the refusal for the installation of a solar farm.
Appeal dismissed
Laughton Wind Farm Ltd. appealed a decision by the West Lindsey Borough Council refusing planning permission for a proposal to build 10 wind turbines.
The court upheld the Inspector's decision.
Informal citizen groups challenged the Inspector's decisions in the High Court of Justice.
The Inspector heard the appeals jointly and overturned the council's decision, allowing for the wind farms to be constructed.
Petitioners challenged the local council's denial of planning applications for the construction of two wind farms.
The court upheld the Inspector's decision.
Residents challenged an Inspector decision granting planning permissions for the installation of a wind turbine.
The High Court of Justice affirmed the local authority's decision on the ground that the project would negatively affect Carnaby Temple, a nearby heritage asset.
NorthCote Farms LTD challenged the decision of a planning Inspector to deny permit for the construction of a windfarm (the decision is dated from 1/08/2014)
The High Court of Justice Planning Court affirmed the judgment of the Planning Inspector.
Permission for wind farm denied.
The court dismissed the appeal finding that the planning policy changes did not warrant reconsideration of the proposal and that all procedural requirements were fulfilled.
Local residents and others challenged the permit for a wind farm (22/09/2011 - permit granted)
The court denied the challenge.
Fight the Fights challenged the decision of the Newham London Borough Council to grant consent to increase the number of flights permitted per year at the London City Airport.
Claim dismissed on the grounds that the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction under the Planning Act 2008.
British high court ordered government officials to consider the implications of climate change prior to making any final decision on a third runway at London's Heathrow Airport.
Claimants challenged the Secretary of State's preliminary approval of a third runway at London's Heathrow Airport.
The High Court denied the request for permission to hold a judicial review over the Treasury's actions.
The decision was upheld.
Swiss International Airlines challenged the EU decision suspending GHG emission allowance trading scheme for some flights to and from the EU, except for Switzerland.
A local resident challenged the district council's decision of granting a planning permission for a pre-case concrete manufacturing facility project.
The court upheld a decision
The Inspector concludes that the costs of the project would outweigh the benefits, the appeal was denied.
The Court upheld the government's decision and found that the Secretary acted within his authority.
Four solar energy companies challenged a decision of the Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change (the “Secretary”ù) to discontinue a renewable energy support scheme.
The Court ruled in favor of Sustainable Shetland.
Sustainable Shetland challenged the Scottish Minister's approval of an application by Viking Energy for the construction and operation of a 457 megawatt Wind Farm
Court ruled that the filmed could be shown undertwo conditions.
Stuart Dimmock challenged the decision to distribute the documentary “An Inconvenient Truth”ù to English state schools as a teaching aid.
The Court ruled in favor of AOWFL and the Ministry.
The Ministry of Energy granted permission to build windfarm in Scottish coast.
Planning permission was granted given that benefits of the plant would outweigh the costs.
Veolia appealed decision to deny permission for a waste to energy facility as an extension to an existing recycling center in Shropshire, England.
The court dismissed the application.
The local planning authority challenged an Inspector's approval of a permit application for a residential development.
The Planning Inspector dismissed the appeal
Yelland Wind Farm Ltd. appealed a decision by the West Devon Borough Council refusing planning permission for a wind farm proposal on the edge of Dartmoor National Park.
The Federal Court then dismissed the appeal on the basis that neither the lower court nor the Minister had fallen into legal error.
The Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) challenged the Minister's decision to approve the opening of the Carmichael Coal Mine.
The Ministry of Environment approved the Adani mining project.
Decision upheld

Event name: Case handed to the Superior Justice Tribunal
Event description: The Case is handed to the STJ for revision
The Federal Environmental Agency fined the appellants (Mr. Filho) for burning roughly 600 hectares of land to clear it for livestock grazing.
The Court ordered the defendants to restore the forest.
The Federal Prosecutor filed a civil proceeding against the group responsible for draining and clearing a mangrove forest and putting a landfill and various structures in its place.
The demandant appealed the decision before the Superior Justice Tribunal (national tribunal).

The demandant sough judicial review of the decision that declared the validity of the penalty and the lack of rights to compensation due to the obligation to reforestate the permanent preservation area in his land.

Event name: Appeal to state court of appeal dismissed

Event description: European Court published questions to the parties.
Greenpeace Nordic and Nature and Youth appealed the decision before the Supreme Court.
Oslo District Court ruled in favor of the Norwegian Government.
Two NGOs sought a declaratory judgment from the Oslo District Court that Norway's Ministry of Petroleum and Energy violated the Norwegian constitution by issuing a block of oil and gas licenses.
The Government of Norway awarded 10 production licenses to 13 companies for oil and gas in the Artic Barents Sea.
Appeal court recognized the complain as admissible, and demands parties to submit evidence.
The court dismissed the claim on the grounds that it was unfounded.
Mr. Liluya,  a Peruvian farmer filed claims for declaratory judgment and damages in a German court against RWE, Germany's largest electricity producer.
The Court found no conflicts between the two documents, but concluded that the Agreement must receive legislative approval before entering into force in Ecuador.

Ecuador's Constitutional Court reviewed the Cooperative Agreement on Climate Change, Conservation of Biological Diversity, and Environmental Development Between the Republic of Ecuador and the Republic of Peru.
The Constitutional Council ruled that the first sentence of art.L.222-2 of the Environmental Code is unconstitutional, rejected the unconstitutionality of the other articles.

The Information Tribunal overturned the decision of the Information Commissioner, determining that if the email still existed then the language of the Regulation required the University to either produce it or issue a valid refusal notice.
Dr. Keiller submitted an appeal to the Tribunal.
Information Commissioner ruled that the email did not need to be produced as its sender no longer had possession or control of it.

Mr. Keiller seeks before the Information Commissioner for the University of East Anglia to provide information that had been requested, which it had denied in 30/10/2009. The information requested was to produce an email and attachment related to an alleged manipulation of data of the historical climate record--the "hockey stick" graph controversy.

The Tribunal rejected the permit application on the grounds that the development plans were at odds with policies encouraging habitat maintenance and biodiversity, and also found that the development would compromise a parcel that would otherwise act as a coastal buffer - a role the Tribunal expected to grow in importance as sea levels rise.
The Construction, which had begun in early March 2009, seeked permission to complete the construction work of a dwelling.
Amendment C45 came into effect in the Glenelg Planning Scheme, which required additional planning permission requirements.
The Court concluded rates could be adjusted in prospect, making it permissible for the Secretary to reduce rates for installations coming online after April 1, 2012, but not in retrospect.

Individuals, solar installation firms and community organizations coordinated by Friends of the Earth challenged the Secretary of State's decision to reduce the rate at which recipients of a FIT for solar would be compensated.
The General Court dismissed the action for annulment as inadmissible, noting that Arcelor is neither individually nor directly concerned by the directive.
Arcelor, steel producer, challenged the validity of the ETS Directive claiming it violated several principles of Community law.
European Court reversed a Commission of the European Communities decision barring the UK from amending its national allocation plan (NAP) under Article 9 of Directive 2003/87.
The European Commission notifies the UK that the amendments to its allocation schemes are incompatible with the Directive.
Land Court recommended that the project be refused or that strict conditions be imposed to ensure that mining will not affect groundwater supplies.

Landowners, the Coast and Country Association of Queensland, and the Mackay Conservation Group challenged the proposal for a large-scale coal mine, arguing that there were significant uncertainties about the impact of mining on groundwater supplies.
Environmental NGOs and individual plaintiffs challenged the sale of a Swedish coal-fired power plant arguing the Swedish government's duty to care for its citizens.
The case was discontinued at the lead plaintiff's request.
Property owners filed a class action suit against Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources seeking compensation for property damages alleging the Ministry should've warned them about flood risks.
The Council's insurers agreed to a settlement.

A group of plaintiffs who own property along in New South Wales, Australia sought damages from the local government authority, the Byron Shire Council, to cover the costs of erecting shoreline protections on their parcels and to compensate for lost value to their properties from encroaching seas.

The Court ruled that climate change is indeed a relevant consideration for the environmental review of the Thabametsi Project. Because the review approved by the Minister ignored climate change, the court held it to be legally invalid.
Earthlife seeks review of the decision of granting the License and of the appeal decision, alleging under CC considerations the License shoudn't be granted.

The Ministry of Environmental Affairs maintains its decision, although it recognises CC impacts should be considered and adds an additional condition to the License: it must undertake a CC impact assessment.
Minister of Environmental Affairs grants authorisation for the construction of a coal-fored power station.

Greenpeace requested that Alberta's Securities Commission freeze, pending review, Kinder Morgan Canada's initial public offering (IPO) based on alleged deficiencies in its prospectus. Case is still undecided.
Global Legal Action on Climate Change (GLACC) filed a petition with the Supreme Court of the Philippines seeking relief from dangers arising from flooding.
the Committee concluded that Greece had indeed violated several articles 2, 3, and 11 of the European Social Charter
Greek Government presented its case and asked the Committee to dismiss the complaint as unfounded.

Marangopoulos Foundation for Human Rights (MFHR) alleged that the Greek government was not in compliance with Greek, European, and international law because of the nature of its oversight (and partial ownership of) several lignite coal mines and coal-fired power plants.

Earthjustice filed a petition on behalf of the Arctic Athabaskan Council alleging that Canada's lax regulations on emissions threaten the Athabaskan people's human rights. Case was filed, it has not yet been decided.

The Court refused to review the Queensland Supreme Court's decision arguing that it is the lower courts' responsibility to determine factual questions, such as the scope of coal mining operations and the nature of the market for coal.
Coast and Country Association of Queensland appealed the decision by the Ministry of Environment to grant permission for new coal mining project.
The Court decided to dismiss the application for judicial review, and mantain the permit that was granted to Adani Mining.
Australian Conservation Foundation, non-profit, challenged the decision to approve a coal mine project.
Minister of Environment grants permission for the construction of a new open-cut coal mine in Queensland by Adani Mining.
The Tribunal decided to grant permission subject to the requirement that the house be elevated per Melbourne Water's recommendation (given possible sea level rise due to CC).
Residents challenged the County Council's decision to permit construction of a two-story house
The Tribunal upheld the denial on the grounds that permission to build in the desired location would put the building in the path of flooding driven by climate change and sea level rise.

Mr. D'Abate challenged the Shire Council's denial of his request for permission to build a new two-story dwelling. The denial was based on the finding that the new building would intensify development in a floodplain.
The Court decided to uphold the appeal, and ordered the Council to grant permission for the development of the dwelling.
Mr. Fetherston appelaed the decision by the Wollongong City Council to deny permission to build a two-story dwelling.
The Tribunal ordered the Council to grant the building permission.
The Tribunal upheld the government's refusal to produce the 11 contested documents.
A journalist challenged the government of Victoria's refusal to produce all of the documents responsive to his request under the Freedom of Information Act 1982.
The Court ruled that the decision by the Council should be upheld, permit is denied.
The couple prepares a new vulnerability assessment and appeals the Tribunal's decision.
The Tribunal upheld the Council's decision.
The Court decided the Council's decision should be upheld, and permission for the development should be denied. The Appeal was dismissed.
Pridel Investments challenges the Council's decision to deny permission for a 39-lot subdivision in Coffs Harbour.
Coffs Harbour City Council denied the permission for a development application by Pridel Investments, because of high flooding risks among other factors.
The Tribunal decided to allow the development and ordered the Council to grant conditional permission for the development.
Applicants seeking permission to develop four joined two-story units on a beachfront plot appealed the city council's denial.
The Tribunal decided to maintain the Council's decision given that the windfarm is in the public's interest.
Local residents challenged approval of a wind farm on various grounds (noise, heritage, culture).
The Surf Coast Shire Council granted planning permit for the development of a wind energy facility.
The Tribunal decided to maintain the Council's decision, but rquired additional conditions relating to the wetlands and protections against sea level rise.
Local residents challenged the Shire council's approval of a development of property 230 meters from the coast and in an area encompassing several ephemeral wetlands.
The Court decided that given the benefits of the windfarm, it should be allowed.
A windfarm developer whose permission to install 9 turbines has been denied, sought judicial review of this decision.
The Tribunal decided the permission for the windfarm should be upheld.
Local residents challenged the grant of permission to develop a 12-turbine windfarm on various grounds.

Shareholders withdrew their suit after the CBA released a 2017 annual report that acknowledged the risk of climate change and pledged to undertake climate change scenario analysis to estimate the risks to CBA's business.
GroundWork, non-profit, filed a motion to revoke the Environmental Affair's authorization to develop a 600 MW coal-fired power plant. The Case is still undecided.
The Court decided to reject the petitioners request.
Petitioners object the approval of a 22-turbine on-shore wind farm, seeking for the Court to overturn it.
The complaint was amended, no decision has been made.

Plaintiffs filed a suit on behalf of 4 Ugandan minors, arguing that under the Constitution it is the duty of the State to preserve natural resources from degradation for both present and future generations.
The High Court ruled against Friend of the Irish Environment arguing lack of standing, but recognized "a personal consitutional right to an environment".
The Court of Appeal rejected the Plaintiffs appeal of the High Court's decision. It is not possible to appeal this decision.
The Claimants the decision of the High Court.
The High Court found the claims were not arguable and denied permission for the case to proceed.
The Claimants appealed the decision of the Administrative Court.
The Adminstratif Court found the Claimants' grounds didn't meet the permission threshold.

Plan B Earth, non-profit, filed a climate change lawsuit against the Secretary of State for Business, Energy, and Industrial Strategy for failing to revise 2050 carbon reduction targets in the light of new international law and scientific evidence.
Supreme Court decided in favour of the plaintiffs, and ordered the government to formulate and implement action plans to address deforestation in the Amazon.
Plaintiffs appealed this decision before the Supreme Court.
Court of Bogotá decided against the plaintiffs.

25 youth plaintiffs between the ages of 7-26 years old sued several bodies within the Colombian government, alleging that climate change and the government's failure to reduce deforestation and ensure compliance with a target for zero-net deforestation in the Colombian Amazon by the year 2020 (target of the National Development Plan 2014-2018) threatens their fundamental rights.

Event name: Advisory opinion issued by Inter-American Court
Event description: The Court provided and advisory opinion with respect to the three rights mentionned (life, integrity and health) saying the Government has a duty to prevent, preserve, provide informationand cooperate.

Colombia requested to the Inter-American Court of Human Rights an advisory opinion concerning the interpretation and scope of articles related to human rights, personal integrityand right to life of the American Convention, this in relation to a healthy environment as a human right.
Nine Indonesian and international environmental groups filed an amici curiae brief in the proceeding before the Denpasar Administrative Court.
Greenpeace Indonesia and 3 local residents challenged the Bali Governor's granting of environmental permits for the expansion of a Coal-Fired Power Plant in Bali.

Ridhima Pandey, a 9-year-old, filed a petition arguing that the Public Trust Doctrine, India's commitments under the Paris Agreement, and India's existing environmental laws and climate-related policies oblige greater action to mitigate climate change. The case is still undecided.

Representatives of the Mataatua District Maori Council filed a claim alleging that New Zealand has breached its obligations to the Maori by failing to implement policies that will address climate change. The case is still undecided.

Mark McVeigh, a pension fund member filed suit against the Retail Employees Superannuation Trust (REST) alleging that it violated the Corporations Act 2001 by failing to provide information related to climate change business risks and any plans to address those risks.
The plaintiffs appealed the decision of the Court.
The Court refused the 6 climate-related claims filed by the plaintiffs.

Friends of the Earth and Plan B Earth, both non-profits, filed a suit against Secretary of State for Transport Chris Grayling (the Secretary) alleging inadequate consideration of climate change impacts in regardsto the expansion of Heathrow Airport. The suit was filed before the High COurt of Justice Queen's Bench Division Administrative Court.
Ontario Regulation 386/18 is adopted

Environmental groups files a lawsuit against Ontario Government alleging it failed to meet legal requirements for public consultation on regulations that would end Ontario's cap and trade program (Regulation 386/18)
The Court upheld the constitutionality of the GGPPA.
The National Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act (GGPPA) is adopted as Canada's carbon pricing system.
Province of Ontario filed a suit in the Ontario Court of Appeal seeking consideration of whether GHG Pollution Pricing Act (GGPPA) is unconstitutional.

Plaintiffs from 6 countries filed a suit against the EU in the European General Court in Luxembourg to challenge the treatment of forest biomass as a renewable fuel in the EU's 2018 revised Renewable Energy Directive (RED II).
The Court sustained the Ministry's decision, arguing that the project was not in thepublic interest since the costs (social, environmental) of the project outweigh it benefits.
Department of Planning denies Rocky Hill Coal Project application.
Gloucester Resources Ltd. filed a lawsuit against the Minister of Planning appealing the denial of the company's project to construct an open cut mine in New South Wales.

Event name: Court dismissed the case (ruling is still pending)
Event description: The Court dismissed the case concluding that the target was not legally binding.

Three german families and Greenpeace Germany filed a lawsuit before the Berlin Adminsitrative Court against the German Govenrment for backing off its 2020 GHG emission reduction target, in violation of the plaintiffs' rights to life and health.

Event name: Rejection of French Government of plaintiffs' request
Event description: Four non-profits, including "Notre affaire a  Tous" (NAAT), sent a request to 12 members of French government as a first stage of a legal proceeding called "Action for failure to act". The French Government rejected this request.
French NGO "Notre affaire à Tous" (NAAT) filed a lawsuit against the French Government before the Administrative Court in Paris due to its inadequate action on cliamte change.

The High Court ruled that the decision was invalid, since the Secretary had not lawfully weighed the relative costs and benefits of tourism and biodiversity as required by NPPF regulations, and the Secretary porvided insufficient evidence to explain why emissions would be reduced if the coal project was denied.

H.J. Banks & Co. Ltd. Challenged the Secretary of Sate for Housing's decision of denying a planning permission for coal mining project on the grounds that it would have adverse effects on GHG emissions.
Case dismissed by Quebec Court of Appeal.
The Court dismissed the motion for authorization of a class action, arguing that the age limits had insufficient justification (among other reasons).

The Canadian NGO "Environnement JEUnesse" filed a case before the Superior Court of Québec to bring action against Canadian Government on behalf of citizens aged under 35, for violating the plaintiffs' rights by setting insufficinet GHG reduction targets.
Supreme Court rules in favour of Friends of the Irish Environment

The Court ruled in favor of the Government rejecting the calim that the Plan was invalid for failing to achieve substantial short-term emission reductions. It also argued that the Plan is an initial step in achieving targets towards a low-carbon and climate resilient economy.
The Irish Government approves the National Mitigation Plan

The advocacy group Friends of the Irish Environment (FIE) filed a suit before the High Court challengin the approval of the National Mitigation Plan as it violated Ireland's Climate Action and Low Carbon Development Act (2015).
Council d'Etat ordering the government to "take all the measures necessary"

The municipality of Grande-Synthe sued the French Government for insufficient action on climate change, before the Conseil d'Etat (highest administrative court in France). This is a a low-lying coastal municipality exposed to sea level rise and flooding.
The Court ruled that the company resolution authorizing construction of the powe plan was legally invalid.

ClientEarth, NGO and shareholder of Enea (utility company) filed a case against the company regarding the construction of a coal-fired power plant. The claim was brought under Polish Commercial Companies Code.

A group of 8 islanders of Torres Strait, Australia filed a case before the UN Human Rights Committee against the government of Australia for violating the plaintiffs' human rights under International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights fue to government's failure to address climate change.
Shell appealed against the court order
The Hague District Court rules in favour of NGO plaintiffs

Friends of the Earth Netherlands and 6 other co-plaintiffs filed a case before the Hague Court of Appeals seeking ruling that Shell must reduce its Co2 emissions by 45% by 2030 compared to 2010 levels and zero by 2050, in line with the Paris Agreement. The underlying argument is that Shell has a duty to take action to reduce GHG emissions based on Art. 6:162 of the Dutch Civil Code (duty of care and human rights obligations by failing to take adequate action to curb contributions to climate change).

The Court decided that Article 10a of Directive 2003/87/EC can be interpreted as Union-wide rules not precluding national provisions, therefore, a after which the applicant has no means of correcting or supplementing its application, may be impossed.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice
Event description: The Administrative Court of Berlin transferred the case to the European Court.

INEOS had requested for additional information to be taken into account for the allocation of its free emission allowances for the period 2013-2020 through an administrative objection filed on 11/03/2014. This objection was dismissed on 3/09/2015 on the grounds that the data was submitted three years later of the deadline (23/01/2012).

INEOS brought an action before the Administrative Court in Berlin for the rejection of its request to take into account additional information regarding the allocation of free allowances for the trading period 2013-2020.

The Court decided that Directive 2003/87/EC precludes national Legislation that taxes, at 80% of their value, greenhouse gas emission allowances allocated free of charge which have been sold or not used by the undertakings subject to the greenhouse gas emission trading scheme.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice
Event description: The Regional Court decided to refer the case to the European Court of Justice.

The Slovak Republic has introduced a tax on emission allowances with effect from 01/01/2011. This tax was later abolished. The Authorities were requesting PPC Power to pay the tax for its activities in 2011. PPC power paid for the first half of 2011 requesting repayment on the grounds that the taxation is contrary to EU Law. This request was rejected, at a demand for the second payment was made.
The Company brought 2 actions against the Tax Administration at the Regional Court of Bratislava, contesting the refusal for repayment and the second payment due for the second semester of 2011.

The Court decided in favour of the Ministry. It held that if the operator failed to comply with its obligation to imely inform the competent authority for the cessation of the operation, then a Memeber State may under Directive 2003/87 request the surrender without full or partial compensation. It also concluded that concluded that the allowances issued after an operator has ceased the activities to which those allowances relate, without informing the competent authority beforehand, cannot be classified as emissions allowances within the meaning of Directive 2003/87.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice

Event description: The application for administrative review was dismissed.
ArcelorMittal borught an application for adminsitrative review against the Decree.

Event name: Request for surrender of emissions without compensation
Event description: The Ministry for Sustainable Development issued a Decree reducing the total emissions allowances for 2008-2012, following the company's cease of operations in 2011, and requesting the surrender of 80922 emission allowances without compensation.
ArcelorMittal brought action against the decision of 24/09/2013 before the Luzembourg Administrative Court.

The Court decided in favour of the company. It held that the Art. 49(1) of Regulation 601/2012 is invalid since it systematically includes CO2 transferred to another installation in the emissions, regardless of weather the CO2 was emitted into the atmosphere.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice
Event description: The Berlin Adminstrative Court referred the case to the European Court of Justice.

The Company Schaefer Kalk (installation for the calcination of lime) requested to the German Emissions Trading Authority (DEHSt) the approval of a monitoring plan which asked for authorisation that CO2 transferred to another installation, but not emited into the atmosphere, should not be considered as "emissions" under Directive 2003/87. This request was rejected by the DEHSt.
Schaefer Kalk challenged this decision before the Berlin Administrative Court

The European Court of Justice ruled in favor of the NEa arguing that: a coal-fired power plan and unburned coal in a storage site constitute one installation covered by the EU ETS, and that coal lost fue to self-heating while in storage could not be regarded as exported fuel for the purpose of monitoring emissions.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice
Nea rejects the objection made by EPZ company
Event description: On 8/11/2013 NEa (Netherland's Emissions Authority) refused to approve the modification of the monitoring plan proposed by EPZ, which the company objected. On April 2014 Nea dismissed this objection.
The Compnay EPZ appealed at the Council State the decision of 23/04/2014.

The Court concluded that a Member State may decline to allocate allowances to an operator for the consumption of heat produced based on the principle that emissions can't be double counted. Member States may also refuse to allocate free allowances for emissions related to the production of measurable heat by burning waste gases.

In November 2013 the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency determined the amount of free emission allowances to be allocated in the third trading period. Eight (8) operators of GHG emitting facilities challenged this decision.
The European Court of Justice decided to uphold the penalty arguing that EU legislature must be allowed to broad discretion in areas that entail policital, economic and social choices.

Event name: Case referred to the EU Court of Justice
Event description: Berlin Court referred the case to the European Court of Justice.

Event name: Fine imposed related to the EU Directive 2003/87/EC
Event description: In November 2011 German authorities requested a report of emissions allowances to company Ziegelwerk Höxter GmbH during insolvency procedure, but company refused because it had ceased activities before the procedure began. German authorities imposed a fine of 100 euros per non-surrendered ton of CO2 equivalent.
Sandra Bitter, in representation of the company, challenged this decision in the Berlin Administrative Court.

The Tribunal decided that the NEMA violated the EIA and Audit regulations by granting the License without the proper particiaption process. It found that the EIA study was incomplete and scientifically insufficient. Also it didn't take into account CC. The tribunal ordered Amu Power Company to conduct a new EIA study in compliance with regulations, it should also include all approved architectural and engineering plans for the plant and its ancillary facilities.
Tribunal visits the site of the Proposed project.

Event name: EIA License issued to Amu Power Company
Event description: The National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA) issued EIA License to Amu Power Comany Limited.
Community in Lamu filed an appeal challenging the issuance of the EIA Licence and the process by which it was obtained.
Court of appeals reversed the lower court's decision, arguing that common law principles only protected private rights.

The Court found that the Defendant had an implied authority. To emit some amount of CO2 in generating electricity, but this amount is limited to a reasonable regard and care for people and the environment.
Defendant's motion for summary dismissal is denied.
Two environmental activists (Gray & Hodgson) suit Macquarie Generation power company, alleging that one of their power stations had been emitting CO2 in a manner harmful for the environment.
The Court dismissed the case on account of delay.
The FCPP issued a retraction and apology on their website.

Michael Mann (scientist) filed a claim against Tomothy Ball, the Frontier Centre for Public Policy (FCPP) and another, for defamatory statements on interview inferring that Mann was guilty of fraud relating to Climategate scandal.
The Court of Appeal for Saskatchewan ruled that the GGPPA is not unconstitutional.

Part 5 of Bill C-74 becomes a law. This is the GHG Pollution Pricing Act (GGPPA) establishes a federal price for GHG emissions in any province/territory that has not implemented carbon pricing regime, effective as of January 2019.
Province of Saskatchewan filed a reference case at the Court of Appeal asking if GGPPA was an unsconstitutional intrusion into provincial jurisdiction.

Plaintiffs file a constitutional petition against the Federation fo Pakistan, alleging inaction on CC violated their fundamental rights: right to clean an healthy environment, and since CC affect women particularly, right to equal protection under the law.

Event name: Case decided by EU Court of Justice
Event description: The Court of Justice concluded that the facility is not entitled to be allocated free emission allowances.

Event name: Case referred to the EU Court of Justice
Event description: The Administrative Court referred the case to the EU Court of Justice for a preliminary ruling regarding if this facility was entitiled to GHG allowances free of charge.

ExxonMobil files a challenge against Germany in the Administrative Court in Berlin regarding the free of charge allocation of GHG emission allowances by the German Emissions Trading Authority (DEHSt).
The Government updated the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF).

The High Court of Justice decided that paragraph 209(a)is unlawful since Government failed to take into account scientific and technical evidence, and since the public consultation process was unfair.

First hearing - claimants present four grounds for challenge of article 209(a): 1) the Defendant failed to take into account technical evidence; 2) Failure to give effect to the Government's policy to reduce GHG emissions (Climate Change Act 2008); 3) Failure to carry out an EIA; 4) Failure to carry out a lawful consultation exercise in relation with the Framework published in 24/07/2018. Article 209(a): "Recognise the benefits of on-shore oil and gas development including unconventional hydrocarbons, for the security of energy supplies and supporting the transition to a low-carbon economy; and put in place policies to facilitate their exploitation and extraction".

The High Court of Lahore decided: to allow the writ of mandamus, ordering the Government to fulfill its obligations under the law. Additionally, it gave instructions to the government bodies to consider revising requirements and penalties under the Trees Act, publish annual reports on expansion of the forest area, impose penalties against delinquent officers, and to issue directions to the housing societies and authorities to support the planting of trees in the green belt and issue penalties for cutting those trees down.

Members of civil society file. Suit against Government of Pakistan for failure to plant, protect, manage, preserve and conserve trees and forests in Punjab, resulting in the violation fo the Forest Act (1927) and the Trees Act (1974). They requested a writ of mandamus.
The ICJ rules how much Nicaragua must compensate Cosra Rica for the loss of environmental services (US$ 120.000)
The ICJ determines Nicaragua's activities are unlawful and violated Costa Rica's territorial sovereignty.

Costa Rica files an action against Nicaragua in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) alleging "incursion, occupation and use by Nicaragua's army of Costa Rican territory and breaches of Nicaragua's obligation towards Costa Rica". Costa Rica sought compensation for the loss of environmental goods and services, due to the removal of 300 trees and clearing of 6 ha of land.

16 children filed a petition alleging that Argentina, Brazil, France, Germany and Turkey violated their rights under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (ratified for the 5 countires) by making insufficient cuts to GHG emissions. They ask the Committee make findings regarding CC as a children's rights crisis, and that each respondent has caused and perpetuates CC by knowingly acting in disregard of avaialble scientific evidence.

The Court decided: it agrees that climate change seriously endangers the future of humanity. Based on the evidence that the Government's objectives will no be achieved, it concluded that citizens in these circumstances can use other means of expression (thay cannot be limited to voting).
The defendants present their case. Experts present evidence on climate change, and the Governments (insufficient) efforts to attain its objectives.
Two citizens (Delahalle and Goinvic) remove from a city hall in Lyon a portrait of President Macron as a protest for non-compliance with the Paris Agreement.

The Court decided that the activities of Trinseo do not fall within the scope of the GHG emission allowance trading scheme established by Directive 2003/87/EC, since it does not generate direct CO2 emissions.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice
Event description: The Administrative court decided to refer the case to the European Court of Justice, the court received the case on 16/11/2016.

Event name: Application for emission allowances free of charge for Trinseo denied
Event description: Trinseo appled for a free allocation of emission allowances for the period 2013-2020, which was denied by the German Emissions Trading Authority (DEHSt) on the grounds that polycarbonate is not included in the list of groups of substances for TEHG. Trinseo appealed this decision, and this appeal was dismissed.
NGO ClientEarth filed lawsuit against Polska Grupa for their plant Belchatow to prevent them from burning lignite. According to ClientEarth, Belchatow is the largest GHG emiter in the EU.
The Court decided to dismiss the action and ordered the Republic of Poland to pay the costs incurred by the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union.
The proposal for the establishment and operation of a market stability reserve for the EU GHG emissions trading scheme is adopted.
Court analyzed case for the first time - administrative judge ordered the parties to provide their written positions on the issues raised.
The Republic of Poland contested EU decision on the grounds that it affects a Member State's choice between different energy sources and the general structure of its energy supply.

Event name: Case referred to the European Court of Justice

Event description: The Court decided: it annulled the E.R. 1113/2018, but considers Chile's international commitments don't impose that climate change is considered in EIA. It annulled the approval of the EIA on other grounds. The operator has appealed this decision.
The plaintiffs file a claim againts E.R. 1113/2018at the Environmental Court of Valdivia.

Plaintiffs present first petition to theExecutive Director of the Environmental Evaluation Service (SEA) to cancel the approval of the EIA of the project “Incorporation of blasting as a complementary method in the mechanical extraction of sterile material in the Winter Mine."
The Executive Director of SEA issues the Exempt Resolution No. 1113 - rejects the pleintiffs petition.

Court decided - it annulled the Environmental Assessment Service's approval of the project since it failed to provide sufficient compensation for disruption to wetlands and forests. It ordered that the assessment procedure be reopened. It also concluded that the EIA needs to only analyze local impacts, hence climate concerns can be excluded.
The plaintiffs present their case at the Environmental Court of Valdivia.

The Executive Director of the Environmental Evaluation Service (SEA) issues the Exempt Resolution No. 0914 in relation to the proposed hydroelectric project Central Hidroélectrica Cuervo in the region of Aysén.
NGO "Notre affaire à tous" (NAAT) files an external contribution at the French Constitutional Council, arguing that the bill does not comply with the environmental obligation of vigilance.
Parlament adopted the Law Energy-Climat
Court found them guilty of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome without permission. They were sentenced to unpaid work hours.
Climate activists occupy northern runway of Heathrow Airport, protesting against airport expansion.
Defendants were convicted of public nuisance, and the judge determined that their conduct crossed the "custody threshold" justifying a sentence of detention.

Protesters block road for 11 hours preventing work to be done. They protest against the authorisation to Cuadrilla by the Oil and Gas Authority to begin fracking to explore for shale gas at a site near Preston New Road.
Trinseo brought legal action against the decision of DEHSt.

INEOS brought proceedings before the Administrative Court in Berlin for the refusal of its request for emission allowances free of charge made on 23/01/2012, denied on 19/02/2014, appealed and denied again in 14/09/2015.
Court of Cassation overturned the judgment of the Versailles Court of Appeal

Event name: Complaint communicated by UN Special Procedures
Dismissal of case against Blackmore et al
High Court judgment overturning acquittal of Angela Ditchfield
Final appeal filed to Supreme Court
Osaka High Court upheld lower court's decision
Activists break into a Credit Suisse branch
Event description: twelve climate activists wearing white sports clothes and wigs staged a tennis match at a Lausanne branch of Credit Suisse to protest the bank's fossil fuel investments and pressure tennis star Roger Federer to end his sponsorship arrangement with the institution

Appeal of the dismissal by the Administrative Court of the challenge to a 2016 government decision to allowing exploratory wells and associated monitoring to test the feasibility of the commercial extraction of shale gas at two sites in Lancashire
Repsol appealed BEIS's Notice of Recovery, bringing three claims before the Tribunal General Regulatory Chamber

a judge of the South African High Court found that the respondents had made several errors and remanded with instructions to, among other things, reconsider the decision's effect on existing rights related to the aquifer "in the context of climate change and water scarcity."
Supreme Court granted leave to appeal.
The ECJ has annulled the Commission’s decision refusing the full access to the documents requested by Saint-Gobain.
Saint-Gobain lodged an appeal before the Court of Justice (ECJ).
The General Court of Justice (EGC)dismissed the action.
Saint-Gobain brought an action against the European Commission decision before the General Court of Justice (EGC).
The Administrative Court, Berlin, referred the question to the Court of Justice.
Evonik Degussa appealed this decision before the Administrative Court in Berlin.
German authorities confirmed their original decision that the hydrogen was already present in the rich gas source streams, and it was not the result of a production by Evonik Degussa.
The German authorities made a decision to allocate Evonik Degussa allowances for the years 2013-2020.
Final statement issued by NCP; concurrence not achieved by the parties.
The Austrian Federal Administrative Court overturned the decision of approval of the construction of a third runway at Vienna's main airport.
The previous decision is repealed, the authorisation for the third runway is granted.
Supreme Court decided to combine all the related cases and will hand down one decision
Supreme Court issued first decision in one related case.

Event name: Filing of Third Further Amended Statement of Claim by claimant

Event description: Court rejected motion

Event name: Judgment in favour of youth claimants

Event description: Supreme Court's rejection of defendant's appeal.

Event name: Federal appellate court's delimiting the powers of the amicus curiae
Case returned to Federal District Court of Curitiba
IEA appeal of transfer deicsion to Federal Appellate Court
Case transferred 7th Federal Environmental and Agrarian Court of the Judiciary Section of Amazonas

Event description: Permission for claim to go to hearing refused

Event name: Main hearing held by District Court

Event description: Admissibility of court granted but injunctive relief dismissed

Event name: Order rejecting government motion to withhold information
Order establishing expert committee on tree cutting
Application admitted by the High Court

Event description: First hearing held on case. Government requested court to declare the complaint inadmissible.

Event name: Granted then suspended by higher court
case referred back to the parties

Event description: Notice to oppose by Minister.
Notice to abide by the President.
ESRG Expert Report. Assessment of new coal generation capacity targets in South Africa’s 2019 Integrated Resource Plan for Electricity.
Expert report climate impacts.
Letter to Minister
Expert report - climate change implications for the youth.
Expert report Garret Barnwell.
High Court determined claim was justiciable
Court issued decision declining to strike out claim
Declaration not approved by Council
Case filed against Danish Crown
Italian Competition Authority Ruling Issued
ASA issues ruling on Shell UK's Shell Go+ campaign
Shell UK Ltd. launches radio advertisement campaign for Shell Go+
Mexican congress appealed District Court's decision to grant an injunction against the contested amendments.
Mexican government and Congress appealed District Judge's decision to admit claim
District Court issued an injunction to suspend the effects of the contested amendments
Court acquitted activists and reclassified offences from serious to light damage

Event name: Original Claim Combined With Other Case
Event description: Claim was combined by the Federal Court of Mar del Plata N. 2 with another lawsuit (Godoy, Ruben v. Estado Nacional) not grounded on climate concerns.
ECJ overturned the General Court's judgment, ruling that the General Court had erred.
EU Commission appealed ruling to the European Court of Justice
EU General Court issues decision (and partially upheld the actions)
Municipality of Madrid files action
City of Brussels files action
City of Paris files action
Decision
Chilean Supreme Court overruled the decision of the Court of Appeal of Antofagasta and upheld the plaintiffs’ appeal.
Court of Appeals of Antofagasta rejected the workers’ claims on procedural grounds.
Ordinance issued by the Italian Supreme Court of Cassation
Judge dismissed Shell and Impact Africa's appeal of the High Court's decision.
The High Court found that the requirements for an interdict were satisfactorily met

Event name: Case dismissed by Federal Constitutional Court
Case dismissed by Federal Constitutional Court
Judgement issued by Council of State

Event description: Case dismissed because government no longer pursuing project being challenged by case.
Application for stay of permit granted, pending substantive review
Appeal ruling found in favour of claimants
Dismissed but appealed by claimants
Based on new evidence presented by defendant

Event name: Supreme Court review of original ruling
Supreme Court upholds Court of Appeal's' decision

Event description: The applicants are preparing a new application to submit to the Dutch National Contact Point.

Event name: Ruling by Supreme Court of Chile
Ruling by Court of Appeals of Antofagasta
Appeal dismissed by  Swiss Federal Administrative Court
Response by China to Special Rapporteurs
Submission of pre-litigation letter to KLM
Judgment on motion for leave to appeal

Event description: Application partially successful (application for review of approval of highway realignment rejected; however, application for review of provision of statement of the decision by Minister may proceed on the merits).

Event name: Application for judicial review of Minister's April 29, 2021 decision
Reply received from Chairs of the OECD Working Group
Submission made to the OECD by Special Rapporteurs
2nd Panel of the  Justice Tribunal of the State of Rio de Janeiro
Event description: Interlocutory appeal dismissed

Event name: Ruling by Special Body of the Justice Tribunal of the State of Rio de Janeiro

Event description: Case to be heard before the Court's Special Body

Event name: Supreme Court granted case in favour of appellant

Event description: Court of Appeal upheld lower court's decision
Trial court struck out the suit

Event name: Court of Justice’s Advocate General issued opinion
EU General Court ordered Poland to pay fine for non-compliance with Order
Vice-President of the European General Court issued an order granting interim measures
